summary: This is a letter from the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of Florida to defense attorney Jack Goldberger, formally notifying him of the individuals the government was prepared to name as victims in a federal indictment against Jeffrey Epstein. The letter is issued as part of the non-prosecution agreement following Epstein's state guilty plea.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The subject of the letter; pleaded guilty to state charges of solicitation of prostitution and procurement of minors for prostitution on June 30, 2008, and was sentenced to imprisonment.

persons.name: Jack A. Goldberger
persons.context: The recipient of the letter, an attorney at Atterbury, Goldberger & Weiss, P.A., representing Jeffrey Epstein.

persons.name: R. Alexander Acosta
persons.context: The United States Attorney for the Southern District of Florida who signed the letter, overseeing the federal non-prosecution agreement with Epstein.

connections.description: Goldberger is identified as Epstein's attorney, receiving official legal correspondence on his behalf.
Acosta, as U.S. Attorney, was the federal prosecutor who entered into the non-prosecution agreement with Epstein.

events.title: Epstein's Guilty Plea and Sentencing
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein pleaded guilty in Palm Beach County Circuit Court to felony solicitation of prostitution and procurement of minors for prostitution. He was sentenced to 12 months' imprisonment, followed by 6 months' imprisonment, then 12 months of community control.

events.title: Formal Victim List Notification
events.description: The U.S. Attorney's Office sends this letter to Epstein's attorney, providing formal notice of the individuals the government was prepared to name as victims in a federal indictment, as required by the non-prosecution agreement.

keyFacts: Jeffrey Epstein pleaded guilty to state charges on June 30, 2008, and received an 18-month custodial sentence followed by 12 months of community control.
The federal government (U.S. Attorney's Office) agreed to defer prosecution in favor of the state plea, under a non-prosecution agreement with specific conditions.
A key condition of the agreement was that identified minor victims would retain the same rights to sue under federal law (18 U.S.C. ยง 2255) as if Epstein had been federally convicted.
This letter serves as the formal notice to Epstein's attorney of the list of individuals the U.S. was prepared to name as victims in a federal indictment.
The document is signed by U.S. Attorney R. Alexander Acosta, who oversaw the controversial non-prosecution agreement.
